key_points: Facebook and its sister properties experienced a six-hour outage on October 4, 2021.
The outage was caused by a configuration change on the backbone routers by Facebook's network engineering team.
The change was meant to assess the availability of global backbone capacity but unintentionally disrupted all connections.
Facebook's fail-safe processes could not prevent the outage due to a bug in the audit tool.
The outage resulted from a machine-based insider event, not a malicious actor.
A DNS error caused their BGP messages to go blank, making Facebook and its services unreachable.
The company's internal infrastructure, including IoT devices and services, was significantly affected.
Work at Facebook had to be managed locally due to the unavailability of remote operation capabilities.
Facebook released two engineering blog posts detailing the cause and impact of the outage.
The incident highlights the potential havoc machines can cause even without malicious intent.
